Posts.Content: I had the dye put in on the morning of my WLE and sentinel node surgery. When I had my second surgery to remove more nodes and get clear margins I did not have another lot of dye put in. My surgery was just over a year ago.
Posts.Title: Radio active dye during lymph node removal

Posts.Content: Hi there,  I completed chemo in April 2016 and radio in May 2016. We went on holiday to France for 2 weeks in August 2016 and then 1 week in Lanzarote in October 2016. I was fine but made sure I didn't try and do too much - I drank plenty of water, wore a hat and used plenty of factor 50 - I really enjoyed my holidays! I also got a letter from my oncologist stating what my diagnosis was, the active treatment I had received and that I was fit to travel. We are fortunate to have travel insurance through my husband's work health policy and they simply asked for a copy of the letter and suggested that I carry a copy with me just in case I did need any medical attention. I'd check with your oncologist but can't see why not. You are not traveling to a country that would raise concerns about medical treatment but do make sure you have travel insurance. Best wishes xx
Posts.Title: Travelling abroad

Posts.Content: Hello, At my breast care unit I was given a small folder of information relevant to me by the BCN after my first appointment. I also spent time with the nurse at the end of the appointment when she went through everything slowly and carefully. It is easy to not hear things properly and to get confused about the information. There will be a lot going on in your head. Do not be afraid to ask for it to be explained again. There should also be a phone number you can call. This site is always supportive and informative. Best wishes x
Posts.Title: First appointment Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Tonight I went out to one of my local folk clubs something I haven't been able to do since I started chemo in December. Whilst I didn't play/perform tonight I did sing along with choruses. Oh it was so wonderful to be back out amongst friends taking part in music. I always feel better after a good sing. (Singing releases feel good endorphins).  I ended up crying tears of happiness and being an emotional mess for good reasons.  I've missed it so much. It has been such a magical night.
Posts.Title: Happy stuff

Posts.Content: So lovely to hear positive happy things are happening for others as well - thank you for sharing them. I do find that being out in the fresh air and countryside for a walk or similar is really uplifting as well. A trip to the seaside sounds wonderful - must try and do this but living in the midlands means it is a long way to the coast. Today I went into work for a visit and was greeted with lots of hugs and smiles - such a positive experience. everyone was pleased to see me but were insistent that I must only go back when I am ready to. There is another folk club next week and I have arranged to play some tunes on my fiddle provided I am not feeling too sore from the radiotherapy.  I have certainly learnt to enjoy simple things and not take for granted how uplifting they can be. i know that they are going to help me as I continue my treatment and recovery. Best wishes xx
Posts.Title: Happy stuff

Posts.Title: Trivial I know in the grand scheme of things but....

Posts.Content: Hi windinsails,  This morning we went out to walk what used to be one of our regular local walks - about 6 miles. I haven't felt up to trying it until now (I finish radio therapy on Tuesday and throughout/since chemo that would have been much too far). I knew it would take us far longer than it used to so wanted to take some drinks and snacks for when I got tired and needed a boost. After a search in the cupboard I found an old 'bum bag' into which i managed to fit my phone, sweets, bottle of water etc so everything did not have to go in my husband's rucksack. The 'bum bag' will certainly be ok for now but not really suitable for when (I hope) we can get back to longer walks and hills. x
Posts.Title: Trivial I know in the grand scheme of things but....

Posts.Content: Hi Bev, I will be having my 6th and final chemo next week. I have gained weight during chemo - I think it is a mixture of not being as active as I usually am (I would be on my feet all day if i was at work and we walk regularly), the effect that losing my sense of taste has on my choices of things to eat (I love fruit and salad but simply can't stand to eat them except in week 3 of the chemo cycle and many of the things I can manage are not the healthiest of foods), not being able to stand the feel of food in my mouth for a few days each cycle, eating 'treats' to cheer myself up and the effects of the steroids. My friend however lost weight during chemo particularly when on T as her mouth was so sore and she had so many ulcers that she barely ate. I was overweight at the start of treatment as attending Slimming World - that is currently on hold.

Posts.Title: Bras - rant!!!!

Posts.Content: We are going on a much awaited holiday to France at the end of next week so I thought I would nip to M&S and buy myself some new underwear. It turned out to be an annoying and upsetting experience. There they were the display stands and row upon row of brightly coloured, assorted styles, pretty lace, funky material, sexy lace under-wired bras (with matching knickers) whilst there were just a couple of stands of non-wired bras in mainly white with a couple of options in black or a kind of beige/flesh colour. My choices were very limited - i just wanted something a bit prettier, and dare I say sexier, than the functional support bras that took up most of the non-wired stand.  I am ok about my slightly mis-shaped boob and my scars, you can't tell that it is smaller and a different shape to the other one when I am clothed. I know I am almost 3 stone overweight but I'm slowly losing the excess and I don't have an issue accepting the oddly shaped flabby bit around my underarm area that is a result of my surgery. Surely it isn't too much to expect to have more choice of bras - maybe something in a funky colour or material, something pretty or sexy that comes with matching knickers? I know that prior to surgery many of the under-wired bras would not have been my fit but I had far more choice. I did manage to buy a couple - one functional and one more lacy (one of only 2 or 3 styles that were available) - but i came home and cried. It just upset me. I know there are other shops I can go to so any recommendations are welcome!
Posts.Title: Bras - rant!!!!

Posts.Content: Wow lots of responses and things to try - I hadn't thought about taking the wires out of my bras but it is certainly worth a try. The thing that annoyed me/got to me was the vast amount of choice for under-wired compared to non-wired. I don't mind having functional practical bras but just fancied something a bit prettier, kind of needed a reminder that I am still feminine and more than just a battered 55 year old.  Iwannaliveforever/Lizz - thanks for the suggestions and advice with regard to our holiday and your offer to meet up. We are going to Pont du Gard early on Tuesday morning (16th) and then on to Uzes for lunch and the afternoon with friends who are staying there. Les Baux is on our list of places to visit and also Arles, Avignon and the roman site just south of St Remy. We may also drive down to the camargue but I'm wary about the reports of insects/mosiquitos I have heard. The plan is to get up and go out early to visit places so that I can avoid being out in the sun during the hottest part of the day.  Best wishes x
Posts.Title: Bras - rant!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi there Lacomtekp/Karen,  We wil be between Avignon and St Remy de Provence for our first week and then near Albi for our second week. I have my factor 50 - I usually use this anyway - plus various hats/head coverings as although I now have hair it is a little bit thin in some places.  I'm a size 18 and 38C - it would be lovely if you could convert this for me then I can confidently have a look when we venture to the shops. Thank you x I did buy a couple of bras today that I am happy with but it was the fact that there were no non-wired bras in any of the lovely colourful or interesting fabrics that really hit me as well as the lack of matching knickers. i've since looked on line at Debenham's and they seem to offer much more choice - still very little choice at M&S on line.  Best wishes x

Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: I am a secondary school teacher and started my phased return with 3 mornings for the last 2 weeks before the summer holiday. I then did 2 weeks of half days before going onto full days in September but on a much reduced work load of 11 lessons rather than the usual 20. I have had this extended until the end of November and my head has said he is ok for it to continue until the end of term. How long can I extend this for? Is there a specific time limit for my work having to accept me on reduced duties? I'm now suffering from the side effects of taking Letrozole and am nowhere near ready to take on more lessons as I'm only just managing what I am doing. I know at some point I will need to look at going part time but don't want to make that decision until I have to.
Posts.Title: How long can I stay on a phased return/reduced duties?

Posts.Content: Lots of interesting posts, thank you.  I am fortunate in that my headteacher is very supportive and to quote "make sure that you are looking after yourself and don't try to do too much". (it certainly would have been very different in my previous school) He is currently happy for me to be in school on a reduced timetable rather than pushing me to increase my timetable and risking me being off because I have done too much. I have days when I just about manage to get to the end of the working day and other days when I am fine. The current problem with my arms is making things more difficult. When I do start to increase my timetable then it will not be my specialist subject which bothers me as it will be more 'stressful'. I really feel for those of you who are in a less fortunate situation. I will be seeing my GP but also need to wait until I have some answers about my current arm problem. The head understands that an increase in my teaching timetable will be gradual so that will also be helpful. I am also considering going down to 4 days. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: How long can I stay on a phased return/reduced duties?

Posts.Content: Hi Sam, I was recently diagnosed and am having my lump and some nodes removed on Wednesday. I was an emotional mess for a good few days after the diagnosis but then calmed down and became more focused and determined. Now the surgery is getting closer I've started to feel anxious again. People on here are very supportive and I also found that there were 3 people at work who have undergone the same procedure. Talking to them really helped.  I'm going to try and deal with things one step at a time even though I am a born worrier. best wishes x

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona,  your post has struck a chord with me. I am now halfway through my radiotherapy and like you have gained weight and am easily tired and often achy. On a more positive note we have booked a 2 week holiday to France in the summer so I have something to look forward to. Best wishes x

Posts.Title: Bathing

Posts.Content: It is interesting how different things are from one place to another. My appointment with the wig lady was a chance to try on a good variety of styles and colours. Once a style was chosen she ordered it in about 7 different colours - the nearest ones to my existing hair. A week later and it was appointment 2 when I tried them all on and selected the one I wanted. She then trimmed it for me to get the style how I wanted it.   I have worn my wig and a variety of head coverings during treatment. My wig has fooled everyone and people have been amazed when they find out it is a wig. At £67 my NHS subsidised wig has turned out to be less money than I would have spent on hair products and hair appointments in the last 7 months plus I can get ready so much more quickly I have tended to wear it mainly when out in public particularly during chemo when I felt vulnerable. I'm comfortable now wearing head coverings in public but still wear my wig if going out for a meal or to an event.  Hope you can find something you feel comfortable with. Best wishes
Posts.Title: Rage at the Wigs!

Posts.Content: Hi there,  when my sense of taste and feeling in my mouth was at its worst I found orange juice ice lollies were good (cold, sharp taste that I could just about make out - needs to be juice not just flavour, I had Waitrose ones via Ocado delivery) I also managed those little pots of Ambrosia custard provided they were kept in the fridge so there were really cold. I don't like flavoured milk but my friend found it good. Best wishes
Posts.Title: Everything tastes so bad!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi, many of you have likened things to a roller coaster and I now understand why. Having had a 2nd surgery because of the results from the first I am now awaiting results again. I am trying to keep my mind occupied as well as recovering from the surgery and doing my exercises but find myself worrying about every little twinge in my body. Backache and stomach ache are causing my mind to run riot and I'm sure that the worry is only making them worse. Wish I could stop this as I'm alternating sleepless nights of worry and fear with ones where I do sleep due to sheer exhaustion. I've tried all my usual tricks to aid sleep but still find myself struggling - probably not helped by having a limited sleeping position due to the discomfort after surgery.  Some days I am fine, the strong woman that so many family and friends say I am but at other times I find myself overwhelmed and in tears that seem to happen unprompted. I assume that this happens to others not just me.   I'm struggling this evening and do not want to burden my wonderful supportive husband anymore today as he has an early start in the morning. I just felt I needed to voice all this, to try and put it into words. Thank you for reading x
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: Thank you very much for all the comments and hugs everyone - it is good to know I am not the only one experiencing this. I can just see me browsing pinterest in the early hours now. I find I feel better/more positive if I get up, shower and get dressed so that is what I have done this morning, I've done the first lot of exercises and been for a short walk in the sunshine. I'm looking forward to feeling able to walk further. I have some needlework I could do, colouring books and plenty of books on my kindle to read but often find it hard to settle to things. I have read several books recently but do not always remember what they were about - I think I need to read more slowly as I tend to rush to find out what happens next. As for weird dreams - I haven't any to report. Hi Patsy plum - I wondered how you were getting on x You are right about the crying - i don't try and pull myself together as it is best to let it happen rater than hold it in. I think my husband is now used to this and just offers hugs or a hand to hold for as long as i need if it happens when he is around. As it is half term I will have a few visitors this week which will help with the low points in the afternoons. Xx
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: Thank you for replying Jj1 and best wishes for your surgery on Thursday x We went out for a gentle walk this morning at a local country park - it was so nice to be in the fresh air and out of the house but this made me tearful. I know that we are doing things to help me feel better and aid recovery but I can't stop myself worrying that we won't have many more opportunities.
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: Well I was originally due to get the results from my second surgery on 3rd Nov but they weren't back in time so now waiting until 10th Nov. Have come away for a short break with my husband which has helped a lot until now. Today I feel overwhelmed again, I don't think it helped that I tripped and fell whilst we were wandering about today. I just feel so 'broken' and 'damaged' and 'useless'. I'm back to worrying that every ache/twinge/sensation is linked and have done a good job of convincing myself that my body has been completely invaded by my breast cancer. I'm normally a logical intelligent person and this is driving me mad.
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: Thank you for replying Grogg. I did smile at the thought of you measuring for curtains at 4am.  I have never used eBay but I might give it a browse, maybe it will help cure the sleeplessness.  It is all the 'what ifs' that bother me. If they need to do more surgery I can't see it being anything other than a mastectomy and I'm kind of ok with that - if they need to remove any more of my breast it would be better to take all of it. It is the worry that it has spread that I am finding the hardest to cope with. After initially being told it was a small early find and likely to be a LWE and rads it then became only one of two nodes were clear and we found 2 other smaller lumps so we need to remove more tissue and nodes. I know this was to get it all out and check how far into the nodes it had gone but it is hard to stem the fears and worries.
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: Thank you Lady Pepys - I appreciated the hug x
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: As a teacher I am used to a very structured day/week and also used to being the one organising things and getting stuff done. I'm finding not having the structure or the control to get things sorted out a bit of a challenge. I'm getting round this by taking charge of what I can which means doing the post surgery exercises - I have made myself a chart and since Thursday have been structuring my day round the 3 short bouts of exercises. This is helping and I also don't feel as guilty about the lazing around reading or using my iPad in between. I think my patience has run out with daytime  TV though. You are correct about night time being the worse although I often find myself 'down' at 4pm for some strange reason.
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: Well I did manage a reasonable amount of sleep but made sure I was awake by 7:30 as I don't want to not be tired tonight. I've found that sleeping longer in the morning means it is harder to fall asleep at night. My mind is still wandering too much and the backache is uncomfortable but it is a bright day so I will go for a short walk later and I have a friend coming to see me this afternoon so things to look forward to. No stars or stickers on my chart Grogg just ticks and numbers - maybe I should award myself some stars for my efforts with the exercises. Progress with the distance I can stretch my arm when doing the 'wall walk' is very slow. X

Posts.Content: I asked about private when first diagnosed as we have cover via my husband's job. It would have been the same surgeon but would have delayed my surgery by a couple of weeks due to having to start the process again. Also I would not have had access to the breast care nurses and I found their support of great value. We asked again before starting chemo but were advised that unless I needed a drug that was not available on the NHS there were no advantages.  Had I chosen to go private I would have been treated in a hospital further away from where I live which in turn would have caused a few problems.
Posts.Title: Private or NHS care/treatment decision

Posts.Content: Good luck tomorrow. I had to have a second surgery (following LWE and SNB) - a cavity scrape and full node removal. I was grade 2 with 3/13 nodes positive and hormone receptive. Although the results were scary I felt better knowing what we were dealing with.  I've just had chemo 5 - one more to go.  The team are fab and so supportive. My husband tells me I am stronger than I think I am - I am now starting to believe him.  Best wishes X
Posts.Title: Results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Funda, I had my last chemo 3 weeks ago (3 FEC, 1T, 2Abraxane). I was 5 years post menopause when I started treatment. I experienced a lot of hot flushes with the steroids but they seem to be continuing. Whilst the flushes have eased off during the day I wake up in the night hot and very sweaty including my head and neck area. I am tending to wake up in the morning in the same way.  It is like the menopause all over again - kick the duvet off or stick my feet out then pull it back again and put my feet on hubby to warm them up.
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and cold at night

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a mammogram/ultrasound/biopsy on the Tuesday and results on the Friday. Surgery was two and a half weeks later. I then had a second surgery just over 3 weeks later and started chemo 6 weeks after that. Chemo would have started sooner but after 2 lots of surgery close together they gave me some extra time to recover. Best wishes x

Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: Hello Little Wren,  The waiting is the hardest part and as the others have said keeping yourself busy is the best thing to do. I also found it good to listen to my iPod at bedtime as this helped me to stop over thinking everything.  Is there a friend who could go with you to your appointment? It helps to have someone with you. I have recently completed chemo after having 2 surgeries to remove a lump and my lymph nodes. It has been tough at times but it is doable and knowing that other people have got through it helps. I'm a worrier and usually try and plan everything well ahead but have learned to take things a step at a time as I had no choice and I've been amazed at how much difference that had made.  Someone reminded me at the start of my treatment that whilst it was new to me it wasn't for the people treating me. They had training and knowledge and for them it was their daily job. I expected people to trust me to do my job so I should put my trust in the team doing their job for me.  This forum is a great support and help -  it is on here where you feel free to ask things no matter how silly you may think they are.  Best wishes x

Posts.Title: EYELASHES!

Posts.Content: I, and i'm sure everyone else on here, know just what you mean. A good friend of mine who has been receiving chemo over a number of years (not BC) gave me the following advice when i started my treatment. "Tears are good as they let out the upset and you don't want that getting in the way of recovery AND it's ok to have a meltdown too.....just don't let yourself unpack and stay there!! You can do this....Try really really hard not to plan/ think ahead.....(because we are trained to do this professionally it's what we do all the time)....but in this we need to stop ourselves doing it.Things change along the journey and all we are doing is exhausting ourselves when we need every ounce of those energy beans. Nothing prepares us for this  .............I tell myself that I have come this far and I'm going to see tomoro and give it everything I've got!"  I'm usually a strong person and my husband tells me I am stronger than i think but 2 nights ago I woke up in the small hours sobbing. I'm finding it hard to just take each day at a time, I get impatient with how tired I am, but I am learning. Sometimes we just need to unload and let it out. best wishes x

Posts.Title: Celebration today ...

Posts.Content: Hi, I was doing slimming world before my diagnosis and treatment. I have found that my appetite and sense of taste during chemo has been considerably disrupted making it necessary for me to simply eat what I can actually stand to have in my mouth. Texture as well as taste has been an issue.  I am just recovering from my last chemo and although I have gained weight it is not something I felt able to deal with whilst undergoing treatment. As my sense of taste returns I will go back to eating more sensibly and hopefully I will be able to enjoy the foods I have found completely unpalatable during treatment.  Slimming world is generally a healthy way of eating.
Posts.Title: Slimming world/ weightwatchers while on Chemo??

Posts.Content: Hi Bev,  I found that the aches began about 3 days after treatment and the soreness in my fingers and feet kicked in shortly after this. I did not suffer from a sore mouth only lack of taste and not liking having food in my mouth but my friend suffered from a lot of mouth ulcers.  Do make sure that you ask for good pain relief if you need it and also let your team know of what side effects you experience. Have you joined the May chemo thread? Best wishes
Posts.Title: Docetexal

Posts.Content: Hello Petrosa,  I was diagnosed in September after a mammogram and initially was reassured that it was probably a small early find. I had a LWE and sentinel node biopsy but then needed the next layer of nodes removed and a cavity scrape as the first surgery showed that there was more than initially thought and some nodes showed cancer cells. This was followed by scans and I am now halfway through chemo.  I am a worrier and had many sleepless nights thinking about all the what ifs - I think we all do. You will receive lots of support on here so don't be afraid to rant and share.  Whilst I don't have a young child I lost my father in July and have an elderly mother with health issues who lives 3 hours drive away. On hearing of this the BCN referred me for counselling - ask your nurse about this as it should be available and will help you.  I still have times when I feel overwhelmed by it all but have learned to try and focus on each day and stage. Waiting for results and the uncertainty is always hard.  Best wishes x

Posts.Title: Waiting forever!

Posts.Content: I'm just beginning my journey having had my lump and 2 nodes removed a week and a half ago. I'm still struggling to come to terms with the fact I have breast cancer and what the future treatment and prognosis might be. There are so many adverts for/about cancer on TV and popping up on my Facebook page which I am finding it hard to cope with them. One which appeared on TV today mentioned thousands of women dying from breast cancer. I am trying to stay positive and keep my mind from wandering to all the 'what ifs' as I await the results that will determine my treatment etc and these adverts are making it harder. I know they are needed to get people to give money to the charities but now I am one of the people they refer to it feels so very different. How do others cope with this?
Posts.Title: Adverts!!

Posts.Content: Hi Obsidianred, thanks for the suggestions - I need to get myself organised as I can do those things. I have been trying to walk out of the room when these adverts start. I don't usually pay much attention to the adverts anyway but obviously these have got to me in my current situation. x
Posts.Title: Adverts!!

Posts.Content: I know that I am just being hyper sensitive at the moment so my logical brain is not operating very well. I am also fully aware of the importance of the adverts in raising awareness and very much needed funds. It is true that we always think that things will happen to other people not ourselves. My mother-in-law had a mastectomy and rads about 5 years ago in her mid 80s and as a family we have contributed to fundraising much more since then.  Whilst I haven't posted about my situation on Facebook (friends know via private messages and FB had been a great way to keep in touch whilst off work and a source of much love and support from them) due to the way the internet and such things work adverts pop up that link to other searches etc you have done.  Since sharing my diagnosis with friends and colleagues I have been surprised by how many of them have direct experience of similar surgery and treatment.
Posts.Title: Adverts!!

Posts.Content: Hi Jane26,  I am due to get my results the same day as you. I don't know anything about my lump except that it is cancer and was about 15mm - I have not been told anything about the type yet. I suspect that you might have seen the same advert that sent me into a bit of a state (the one where they say how many thousands of women die from breast cancer). I was doing ok with the other adverts I had seen but that one just sent me into a panic and tears. It is so hard to 'keep it together' and not be in a state of constant worry. I keep reminding myself of the 6 people I know personally who have come through all of this and are living full lives a good number of years after their treatment. Sending you hugs x

Posts.Title: Body lotion

Posts.Content: I completed chemo in April and now have a decent covering of hair. It is much thicker at the back and sides plus is very curly - have nicknamed it my granny perm. It is shorter on top and is taking longer to grow back plus it is either flat or sticking up in random places but is tameable into being encouraged to go in one direction with a bit of mousse. I suspect it may also become curly on top.  It isn't as grey as I thought it would be - hadn't seen my natural colour for years and my mum says it is generally darker than it used to be.  A friend who completed her chemo 9 weeks before me had hers coloured using an organic vegetable based product from Holland and Barrett I think.

Posts.Title: Back from hospital after DIEP

Posts.Content: Hi Jen,  Working during chemo treatment depends on how you are on the treatment and what the demands of your job are. I know that there are a number of people on here who have worked and those like me who have not. Some people seem to work in week 3 of each cycle when you generally feel better. I am a secondary school teacher and apart from the fact that I simply would not have had the energy to do my job nor would I have been well enough to cope with it I was advised that it could be dangerous for me to work due to contact with lots of people carrying germs etc.  There is a lot of information on here about side effects and what helps plus you can also join us on the April chemo thread. We are all different and will experience side effects to a different extent. Some people have very few and continue to work apart from a few days each cycle. You will not know how you will be until after your first session. I think there are certain protections whereby your employers cannot put pressure on you with regard to when you work but others will be able to advise more about this. You are not messing people around! You do not yet have sufficient information nor knowledge to answer their questions.  Do check out the information on here about how to prepare for chemo. There are also some threads about working if you search. Best wishes
